title: White House, Iran Ease Tensions
summary: The interest in sparing lives expressed by both sides spurs hope for a diplomatic solution. Rising tension between the U.S. and Iran eased at least temporarily on Friday after President Trump said he called off a planned military strike in order to spare Iranian lives, a development that opened the way for offers of diplomacy from other world leaders.

title: U.S. Targets China's Supercomputing Push With New Export Restrictions
summary: Commerce Department cuts off five Chinese developers from American technology, slashes licenses to U.S. tech companies to hire Chinese nationals. The Commerce Department on Friday took its broadest swipe yet at China's supercomputing industry, imposing new export restrictions that effectively bar five major Chinese developers of next-generation, high-performance computing from obtaining U.S. technology.

title: Iran Calls Trump's Bluff
summary: The President is caught between hawkish goals and dovish means.. President Trump called off a military strike against Iran in mid-mission Thursday, and his supporters and even some of his critics are hailing it as an act of restraint and courage. The question for American interests is whether Iran and other adversaries will see it instead as a sign of weakness and indecision.

title: AT&T's Government Distress Signal
summary: Look who wants the feds to help with a price negotiation.. The Justice Department sued to block AT&T 's merger with Time Warner on grounds that it would increase the telecom company's leverage in contract disputes. There was no real-world evidence to support this, and now there's real-world evidence refuting it. Witness how AT&T is now begging the government for help in price negotiations with local broadcast stations.

title: Who Makes the Law?
summary: The Supreme Court's conservatives may revive Congress's role.. In eighth-grade civics, students learn that Congress makes the law, the executive enforces the law, and the judiciary interprets the law. The Founders designed this separation to prevent one branch from getting too much power and threatening liberty. Yet in today's sprawling administrative state, things aren't so simple. Too often Congress passes laws stating vague objectives and leaves it to executive-branch officials to work out the controversial details-the real work of legislating.

title: Former Barclays CEO Acquitted in Qatar Fundraising Fraud Case
summary: U.K. Court of Appeal dismissed the criminal fraud charges against former chief executive of Barclays in capital-raising case. An appeals court dismissed criminal fraud charges against a former chief executive of Barclays PLC, the U.K. Serious Fraud Office said Friday.

title: Half Dozen Investors Bidding for Anbang Hotel Portfolio
summary: Groups are bidding $5.5 billion and more for portfolio that includes 15 luxury hotels. The field of investor groups bidding for the luxury hotel portfolio owned by a Chinese insurer has narrowed to about a half dozen, with bids ranging from about $5.5 billion to $5.8 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Anti-Money-Laundering Watchdog Calls for Stronger Cryptocurrency Regulations
summary: Financial Action Task Force says virtual currency firms should develop procedures for sharing customer information with other financial institutions. The global standard setter for anti-money-laundering laws called on countries to apply more scrutiny to virtual currency firms that transfer customer funds.

title: Magazine Writer Says Trump Assaulted Her in Mid-1990s
summary: President has denied the allegations, saying he had never met writer E. Jean Carroll. WASHINGTON-A veteran magazine writer has accused President Trump of sexually assaulting her in a New York City department store more than 20 years ago.

title: Supreme Court Reaffirms Rule Against Racial Bias in Jury Selection
summary: Justices vote 7-2 to overturn murder conviction of black defendant in Mississippi. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday reaffirmed its strict prohibition against racial bias in jury selection, voting to overturn a black defendant's murder conviction in Mississippi after a white prosecutor dismissed 41 of 42 African Americans possible jurors over the course of six trials for the same crimes.

title: Jussie Smollett Case Faces New Probe by Special Prosecutor
summary: Judge's order opens up possibility that 'Empire' actor could see renewed charges. A special prosecutor will be named to investigate the handling of the case against Jussie Smollett, opening up the possibility that the actor who was accused of faking a hate crime against himself could face renewed charges.

title: The Turnabout on Religious Freedom
summary: Liberals used to favor broad claims of liberty. Prof. David Skeel says the Obama-era culture wars helped change that.. In an age when contentious historical monuments are targeted for destruction, the Supreme Court decided Thursday to let one stand. At issue in American Legion v. American Humanist Association was whether a 40-foot concrete Latin cross on public land violates the First Amendment's Establishment Clause: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion." By 7-2, the justices said it doesn't.

title: The $15 Minimum Wage Will Put Me Out of Business
summary: My employees already make $22 an hour with tips. A new bill will force me to fire them all.. Want to earn a living wage in Alabama? Try working in a full-service restaurant.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Elitism of 'Woke' Ideology
summary: 'The woke elite act like white saviors who must lead the rest of the country, including racial minorities.'. Zach Goldbergwriting for Tablet, June 5:

title: Putinism in the Dock for Airliner Shootdown
summary: The Kremlin's chief ideologist is cited by Dutch prosecutors as providing the murder weapon.. The prosecution of Russian agents in the 2014 shooting down of a Malaysian airliner over Ukraine has given Vladimir Putin one more reason not to relinquish power when his term ends in 2024 even if the Russian Constitution says he must.

title: The Quiet Death of a Notorious Harlem Drug Kingpin
summary: Like a character out of Shakespeare, Nicky Barnes lived a life of excess, betrayal and tragedy.. I am not the guy you'd expect to know a 1970s heroin kingpin, but I knew Nicky Barnes pretty well. While the notorious Harlem drug trafficker died in 2012, the public only learned of his death this week via a report in the New York Times.

title: Tyson Foods, Boeing, Slack: Stocks That Defined The Week
summary: Resume Subscription. The S&P 500 surged to a record Thursday, as major indexes rallied this past week after the Federal Reserve hinted Wednesday of possible interest-rate cuts if the economic outlook doesn't improve.

title: Newsom Proposes Wildfire Fund to Bolster PG&E, Other Utilities
summary: Governor's plan is designed to help companies cover fire costs that have threatened their solvency. SACRAMENTO, Calif.-Gov. Gavin Newsom is proposing a multibillion-dollar wildfire fund to help California's utilities cover mounting fire-related liability costs that have threatened their financial health.

title: Philadelphia Refinery Fire Contained But Still Burning
summary: Officials monitoring blaze after explosion rocks East Coast's largest refinery, pushing gas futures higher. A fire that erupted following an explosion at a major oil refinery in south Philadelphia was contained but still burning late Friday afternoon, officials said, adding that there were no serious injuries.

title: 'The European Guilds' Review: Of Standards and Strangleholds
summary: As an economic analysis of one of the most important institutions in medieval and early-modern Europe, Sheilagh Ogilvie's book succeeds brilliantly. Only when she tries to draw broader conclusions about how institutions affect growth and prosperity does it fail to convince.. Sheilagh Ogilvie's compendious history "The European Guilds" serves two distinct purposes. As an economic analysis of one of the most important institutions in medieval and early modern Europe, covering almost a millennium of European history, her book succeeds brilliantly. Only when she tries to draw broader conclusions about how institutions affect growth and prosperity does it fail to convince.

title: 'Emperor' Review: A Sovereign on the Move
summary: What was it like to be Charles V?. Benjamin Disraeli, the 19th-century British prime minister, called biography life without theory. Its arc, he suggested, provides structure enough without some grand explanatory system-and reveals a great deal, along the way, about the times in which a life is lived. Geoffrey Parker's "Emperor: A New Life of Charles V" provides a masterly example of biography as just such a window on the past-on early modern Europe, in all its dynastic rivalry and imperial unrest.

title: How Should We Deal With Imperfect Heroes?
summary: I don't judge a work of art based on the character of the artist, and I will not judge Martin Luther King's achievements based on his personal life. He brought this country out of the Dark Ages of Jim Crow racism, and that is what he should be remembered for.. Regarding Lance Morrow's "A Reckoning With Martin Luther King" (op-ed, June 18): I don't judge a work of art based on the character of the artist, and I will not judge MLK's achievements based on his personal life. He brought this country out of the Dark Ages of Jim Crow racism, and that is what he should be remembered for.

title: Slippery Slope of Human Organ Harvesting
summary: Dame Cicely Saunders said: "The question of how one feels about so-called 'rational suicide' is, I believe, ultimately governed by the question of how much faith one has in human nature.". Regarding F.H. Buckley's "Euthanasia and Organ Harvesting" (op-ed, June 18): One person who would not have been the least bit surprised by the ghoulish turn that so-called "rational suicide" has taken-the proposal that organs be donated while the donor is still alive-was Dame Cicely Saunders (1918-2005), the promoter of civilized end-of-life hospice care for the terminally ill in Great Britain, and one of the great women of the modern era. In a television interview given shortly before she died, Dame Cicely said: "The question of how one feels about so-called 'rational suicide' is, I believe, ultimately governed by the question of how much faith one has in human nature. In my case, I have very little faith in human nature. I am absolutely certain that, if society embraces this concept, 'right to die' is going to devolve very quickly into 'duty to die.'"

title: Oberlin's Management Has Disgraced Itself
summary: As for Oberlin College, where were the adults in the room?. I was saddened to read William A. Jacobson's "Oberlin Pays for Smearing the Town Grocer" (op-ed, June 12) about Oberlin College. Over 40 years ago, I graduated from Oberlin where I met the woman who is my wife. It was a daily treat for us to go to Gibson's in the afternoon for its delicious and still warm whole-wheat doughnuts. A major reason that I was attracted to Oberlin was its long commitment to progressive causes. Oberlin was among the first colleges anywhere to admit both African-Americans and women.

title: How Do Human Consciences Develop and Propagate?
summary: Morality lies in choice, and if our actions are determined only by genetically inherited or culturally influenced biochemistry, then morality ceases to exist.. Andrew Stark is too generous in his review of "Conscience" by Patricia S. Churchland (Bookshelf, June 13). What she describes as morality isn't morality at all. Morality lies in choice, and if our actions are determined only by genetically inherited or culturally influenced biochemistry, then morality ceases to exist.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Property Owners in Local Land-Use Case
summary: In 5-4 decision, high court eases property owners' ability to challenge local regulations in federal court. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday made it easier for property owners to challenge land-use regulations and seek compensation from the government, a ruling that revealed deep divisions between the court's conservative and liberal camps.

title: Stocks Post a Winning Week
summary: Equities fueled by signal from Fed that it could cut short-term rates if economy worsens. U.S. stocks notched a banner week, fueled by a signal from the Federal Reserve that it could cut short-term rates in the months ahead if economic conditions worsen.

title: Trading Volume Soars on 'Quad Witching' Day
summary: Heavy trading took place Friday as major indexes rose for third consecutive week. Traders had a busy day Friday, as it marked a quarterly collision that they call "quad witching."

title: Hardware Startups Struggle to Cope With Tariffs on Chinese Goods
summary: Companies are raising prices, changing sales strategies and evaluating new production locations as a way to counter higher costs. Many American startups, especially consumer-hardware makers, are facing difficult choices as they cope with escalating trade tensions.

title: Stocks Are on a Tear. What's Holding These Exchanges Back?
summary: Several big exchange operators and brokerages have underperformed U.S. stocks this month as major indexes have rallied. In the best June so far for U.S. stocks in decades, shares of some brokerages and exchange operators-venues where investors can trade stocks themselves-are lagging.

title: Just One Tilton Company Has Sold as Deadline Looms for Zohar Peace Pact
summary: Storage tank maker Denali is only company backed by financier Lynn Tilton to reach a deal during prolonged cease-fire with creditors. Not enough money has been raised in sales of businesses controlled by Lynn Tilton to lock in an extended peace pact with backers of her Zohar collateralized loan obligation funds, according to a lawyer for the bankrupt investment vehicles.

title: Gasoline Prices Jump on Refinery Fire
summary: Futures extend gains amid rising tensions between the U.S. and Iran. Gasoline futures rallied Friday after a large explosion and fire broke out at a Philadelphia refinery.

title: Big Banks Ace First Round of Federal Reserve's 'Stress Tests'
summary: Fed says largest banks could continue to lend in a severe economic downturn. WASHINGTON-The biggest banks in the U.S. have enough reserves to continue lending in a severe economic downturn, a sign that firms a decade into an economic expansion are faring better in annual "stress tests" despite increasingly dire hypothetical scenarios.

title: Companies Struggle to Adapt to the Justice Department's Stance on Instant Messaging
summary: Questions linger following the rollback of a prohibition on disappearing-message apps. Companies are facing tough decisions about how to comply with U.S. Justice Department guidelines on employees' use of disappearing-message apps after officials reversed a ban on the apps in a program for businesses accused of foreign bribery, lawyers say.

title: PayPal's Stock Drops After Management Move
summary: Fintech company's operating chief is the second member of CEO's inner circle to step down this year. Potential increased competition in the payments space wasn't enough to end PayPal Holdings Inc.'s rally, but a management shake-up might be.

title: Carnival's Foul Forecast Isn't Clearing Up
summary: Cruise line warns of more trouble in earnings.

title: Barr Looking Into U.S. Finding That Russia Wanted Trump to Win
summary: Intelligence officials express concern that attorney general will challenge 2017 assessment. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr's review of the origins of the Russia investigation is focused in part on the U.S. intelligence assessment that found Moscow intervened in the 2016 presidential election to help then-candidate Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Investors Unload Pemex Bonds on Rating Fears
summary: Mexican state-owned energy company is on brink of being downgraded by two major ratings firms. Global debt investors have a $100 billion Petróleos Mexicanos problem.

title: Painting With a Bebop Spirit
summary: Willem de Kooning's "Asheville" is a colorful, almost hallucinatory work with a sense of motion as bristling and vivid as the jazz music of its time..

title: Your Health Plan Could Soon Look Like Your 401(k)
summary: Next year companies can start paying employees to find their own health insurance under the revived Health Reimbursement Arrangements program. A landmark change will soon give more American workers control over their health-care coverage, but be warned: There are pitfalls.

title: Democrats vs. McDonald's
summary: Has any fast food chain ever claimed that its entry-level wages can support a family?. During the brief moments each day when Democratic presidential candidates aren't ranting about Donald Trump, they often discuss their plans to prevent robots from taking our jobs. And then they encourage businesses to buy more robots.

title: NASA Worries Its Moon Rocks Will Moonwalk Away
summary: Resume Subscription. Darby Dyar, a professor at Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts, works in a high-security environment designed to meet federal protocols to protect the materials she studies.

title: Iran Tensions Could Prompt Cyber Attacks, U.S. Fears
summary: Researchers say they have seen suspected Iran-backed phishing attacks target government and private sector in past week. Iran may attempt to retaliate against the U.S. with disruptive cyberattacks if tensions between the two nations over a series of incidents across the Middle East continue to escalate, according to current and former U.S. officials, as multiple cybersecurity firms said they had already seen signs Tehran is targeting relevant computer networks for intrusion.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Egyptians mourn former president, U.S. women's soccer team defeats Sweden, archbishop celebrates first mass in Notre Dame Cathedral since it went ablaze and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: European Auto Makers Are Under Pressure to Sell More Electric Cars
summary: Auto industry in Europe could face fines in the tens of billions of euros unless it ramps up sales of electric cars. BERLIN-An approaching target for tougher new carbon emission standards in the European Union is causing panic among unprepared car makers.

title: What to Stream This Summer: 12 TV Series With Binge-Worthy Décor
summary: The set decoration in these shows will keep design-lovers riveted. Plus: The pros behind them share decorating strategies work well in real-life rooms, too.. IN MY HOUSE, the fastest way to torpedo a perfectly good Friday night is to reach for the remote control without a plan. I'll start by staring down the offerings on Netflix, a digital Hydra that sprouts two new series for every one you contemplate. My husband will then request a due-diligence scroll through Amazon Prime, Hulu and our ever-more-dejected DVR. By the time we've done the rounds, we're too sapped to make a decision.

title: Faltering Factories Cast a Dark Cloud Over Global Economy
summary: Slowdown in factory output worries policy makers at central banks. Manufacturing is faltering in the U.S. and a number of key economies around the world, darkening the outlook for the global economy and increasing the likelihood that central banks will ease policy to provide support.

title: U.S. Existing-Home Sales Rose in May
summary: Demand for housing picks up as mortgage rates continue to ease. WASHINGTON-Sales of previously owned homes rose in May, a sign that falling mortgage rates could be nudging the housing market toward a modest spring performance after a sluggish start to this prime selling season.

title: 'Euphoria': A Long-Lived Term For a Transient High
summary: The title of a new HBO series featuring teens and drugs has often been applied to a misleading sense of bliss. HBO's controversial new drama "Euphoria," which premiered last Sunday, depicts thrill-seeking high-school students chasing the titular emotion, though their euphoric highs-largely fueled by sex, drugs and alcohol-inevitably come crashing down.

title: Trump Maneuvers Near a War He Doesn't Want
summary: The president, who has empowered an antiwar bloc within his own party, now finds his options limited in confronting Iran. At the rally this week officially kicking off his re-election campaign, President Trump boasted that he withdrew the U.S. from the "disastrous Iran deal and imposed the toughest ever sanctions" on Tehran. In the very next passage of his speech, he declared that he is "starting to remove a lot of troops" from the Middle East because "great nations do not want to fight endless wars."

title: U.S. Team and Soccer Federation Agree to Mediation in Pay-Equity Suit
summary: Players and their employer agree to begin mediation process after the current World Cup ends. DEAUVILLE, France-The U.S. Soccer Federation and the 28 players in the U.S. women's soccer team player pool suing it for pay discrimination have tentatively agreed to pursue mediation after the World Cup ends, according to people familiar with the situation.

title: Legal Weed Is Smoking in Seattle
summary: A study analyzed wastewater to gauge the amount of pot consumed locally in the Puget Sound area. Drug dealers probably don't spend much time reading scientific journals, and maybe they shouldn't bother with this one either-it's sort of a buzzkill.

title: Fed's Brainard: Most Likely Path for Economy Remains Solid
summary: Official says important downside risks have emerged in recent weeks. A top Federal Reserve official said Friday that a number of risks to the economic outlook have emerged in recent weeks and echoed some of her colleagues' openness to lowering interest rates.

title: The Problem With Buying Dinosaurs
summary: Scientists worry that a booming market in fossils means higher prices and potential frauds.. Dinosaurs are in the news these days, but it's not always for happy reasons. While paleontologists are making groundbreaking discoveries, their work is often overshadowed by outrage that yet another fossil has been auctioned off to the highest bidder. The most recent controversy involves a rare "baby" T. rex currently listed on eBay for more than $2.9 million, but similar auctions are common. The same vendor also lists on its website an "authentic" triceratops skeleton for $890,000.

title: Two Fed Doves Make Case for Central Bank Rate Cuts
summary: Minneapolis Fed leader Kashkari joined another official to say the central bank should have lowered and not held steady its short-term rate target. Two Federal Reserve officials said they believed the central bank should have lowered and not held steady its short-term rate target this week to help address persistently weak inflation pressures and rising economic risks.

title: Wisconsin High Court Upholds Lame-Duck Session That Limited Governor
summary: In its 4-3 ruling, the conservative majority on the state's highest court called the December session constitutional. The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Friday upheld a lame-duck session that limited the powers of Democratic Gov. Tony Evers and Attorney General Josh Kaul.

title: More Duck-Boat Workers Are Indicted in Sinking That Left 17 Dead
summary: General manager and operations supervisor at Ride the Ducks Branson were charged with misconduct and neglect. A federal grand jury has indicted two more employees of a company that owns a duck boat that sank on a Missouri lake last summer, killing 17 people.

title: House Committee to Subpoena Trump Associate Felix Sater
summary: Real-estate developer was a no-show for scheduled interview. WASHINGTON-A House of Representatives committee investigating President Trump's interactions with Russians during the 2016 presidential campaign will subpoena former Trump associate Felix Sater after he failed to appear for a voluntary closed-door interview on Friday.

title: Skydiving, Mountain Climbing and Other Ways CEOs Terrify Their Shareholders
summary: At work, top executives are asked to walk the knife edge between calculated risk and recklessness. No wonder so many fly planes in their spare time.. I've been a Mount Everest junkie since college, and the 11 deaths there this season got me wondering about risk and death and, oddly enough, the fiduciary responsibility that corporate leaders have to stay alive.

title: Pence to Postpone Address on China Ahead of Trump-Xi Meeting
summary: Pence to hold off on speech amid 'positive signs' of progress with China. WASHINGTON-Vice President Mike Pence will postpone his planned speech on China policy next week to avoid stoking additional tensions ahead of President Trump's planned meeting with China's President Xi Jinping later next week, a senior administration official said.

title: Children's Books: The Island Girl & the Royal Plot
summary: An engrossing graphic novel of political intrigue inspired by the life of Elizabeth I.. Growing up in a remote island convent, 11-year-old Margaret has long wondered about her origins. From her assiduous quizzing of the sisters of St. Elysia, the girl knows that she was brought to the island as a baby, but she doesn't know why. Margaret's true identity is but one of the mysteries woven into "Queen of the Sea" (Walker, 394 pages, $24.99), an engrossing graphic novel by Dylan Meconis set in an alternative Tudor realm in which England is Albion, Scotland is Ecossia, and the Virgin Mary and Jesus are known as the Mournful Mother and the Sorrowful Son.

title: Hong Kong's Flickering Hopes for Freedom
summary: The government's retreat in the face of massive protests was an unexpected win for the territory's citizens, but they are unlikely to prevail against Beijing in the long struggle to maintain their rights. Last week, two days after one of the most violent protests in Hong Kong since China resumed control of the territory in 1997, Thomas, a 20-year-old medical student who declined to give his last name, was still helping to clean up and replenish supplies at an emergency medical station outside the headquarters of the territory's government.

title: How to Reduce Your Risk of Heart Disease
summary: Progress has stalled in reducing the cardiovascular disease death rate. Here are some things you can do to protect yourself. The death rate from cardiovascular disease is rising for middle-aged Americans. Here are some things you can do to reduce your risk.

title: Heart Attack at 49-America's Biggest Killer Makes a Deadly Comeback
summary: Younger people, women and nonsmokers are more likely to be victims of the crisis in cardiovascular health, driven by skyrocketing obesity and diabetes. One of America's greatest achievements over much of the past century has been a huge decline in death rates from heart disease and strokes. Anti-smoking campaigns, medications to control blood pressure and cholesterol, and surgical advances have extended millions of lives, fundamentally reshaping the U.S. population.

title: Baseball's Daffy Pitch for a Combination Tampa Bay-Montreal Franchise
summary: Is a shared franchise between two nations a bad idea...or an idea that's so bad, it's kind of genius?. I was going to write about Zion Williamson getting picked No. 1 in the NBA draft. But I can't. Not today, my basketball friends.

title: At Least Three People in Running to Head FDA
summary: Acting head Norman Sharpless seeks the position, but a Harvard medical center chief executive is also under consideration. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is considering at least two other candidates for the high-profile post of permanent commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, in addition to acting commissioner Norman E. "Ned" Sharpless, according to people familiar with the situation.

title: 'The Most Fun We Ever Had' Review: An Assured Debut
summary: Claire Lombardo's first novel gives a sympathetic but unsentimental look at sisterly intrigues, dinner-table debates and petty resentments.. 'The most Fun We Ever Had," an assured first novel by Claire Lombardo, begins and ends with a celebration. In between there's an untimely death and a few close calls; several unplanned pregnancies; lies, secrets, betrayals and quarrels; shouting (a lot of shouting), a still birth, a heart attack and the sudden appearance of a teenager who had been given up for adoption as a newborn.

title: Citigroup Beefs Up Investment Banking Ranks
summary: Seeking to bolster its investment banking business, Citi has poached several key bankers from rivals Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs and Barclays. Citigroup Inc. has poached a clutch of U.S.-based senior investment bankers from rivals, as it looks to challenge Goldman Sachs Group Inc., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Morgan Stanley for a spot among the top three investment banks globally ranked by revenue.

title: 'Nature's Giants' and 'Superlative' Review: Wild, Wilder, Wildest
summary: Exploring the fact and fiction of 'anatomical outliers,' nature's improbable giants.. We live in a world we barely understand. Even though air travel and the detail of Google Maps have made the world seem smaller, and we're daily bombarded with news from all over the globe, life on Earth may as well be alien to us. Researchers estimate that there are 8.7 million species on this planet. This is no doubt a gross underestimate, and even the species we know of can remain mysterious.

title: Mysteries: The Dangers of Listening to Podcasts
summary: New mysteries by Denise Mina and Kate Atkinson, as well as Soji Shimada.. In Scottish author Denise Mina's "Conviction" (Mulholland, 376 pages, $27), Anna McDonald of Glasgow has gone to great lengths to keep her shocking back story secret-even from her husband. A rape victim nearly killed for identifying her famous attackers, she fled home, changed her name and has been living ever since as the low-profile Anna. But her life is thrown into disarray again when her spouse leaves her for her best friend, taking their two little girls.

title: Garmin Co-Founder Put GPS at People's Fingertips
summary: Garmin co-founder Gary Burrell saw satellite navigation easing everyday life.

title: Science Fiction: Formerly Known as the United States
summary: Reed King's novel imagines a world in which the United States breaks up and becomes the area 'Formerly Known as U.S.A.'. Every science-fictionauthor faces the same problem. Sci-fi has to be set in a world that's somehow different, or else it wouldn't be sci-fi. The reader has to be told what the differences are, and what caused them. But this vital information has to be gotten across without holding up the story.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Mega-Ship Shopping; Apple's Core Conflicts; Oiling the Waters
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: 'Mendeleyev's Dream' and 'Elemental' Review: Cracking the Chemical Code
summary: Dmitri Mendeleyev hit on a way to arrange the elements that not only explained their commonalities but predicted substances not yet known.. On a cold, snowy morning in February 1869, Professor Dmitri Mendeleyev was preparing to make a 300-mile journey from his home in St. Petersburg to a gathering of cheese makers. While the distinguished chemist sat at breakfast reading his itinerary, he turned the sheet to jot down an idea. He forgot about cheese, missed his train and after several days of intense effort arrived at the discovery for which he is famous: the periodic table of elements.

title: Fiction: Friendships, Rivalries, Hierarchies & Reversals
summary: Three novels of women-some strong, others passive-in fraught relationships with one another.. Anyone who pays attention to book publishing will have noticed the rise of a particular breed of novel-one written by women about friendships and rivalries among women, in which men figure as not much more than accessories. For years these books were sorted into the genre category of chick lit, but gradually they've come to dominate the main literary currents, exemplified by critical and popular successes like Meg Wolitzer's "The Female Persuasion" and Elena Ferrante's Neapolitan quartet. Far from a fad, this is an overdue realignment reflecting market forces, as all studies show that women read significantly more fiction than men. For there to be a resurgence of stories exploring the vicissitudes of masculinity, guys are going to have to start buying more novels.

title: Five Best: Steve Fraser on Social Class
summary: The author of 'Class Matters: The Strange Career of an American Delusion' recommends fictional explorations of the subject.. By Edward Anderson (1935)

title: 'A Primer for Forgetting' Review: The Past Need Not Be Prologue
summary: Human beings-and human societies-cannot change or grow without learning to let go.. Lewis Hyde's new book is so counterintuitive, so bracingly clear and fresh, that reading it is like leaping into a cold lake on a hot hike. It shocks the mind. It flushes all kinds of monotony and mental fatigue right out of your system. I have filled a notebook with things from this book I am determined to remember, which is quite a paradox, given that it's a book about forgetting.

title: 'Thomas Harriot' Review: A Genius in Eclipse
summary: He was the first to study the moon through a telescope, the first to explain the physical cause of a rainbow and first to deduce the mathematics of free-fall decades before Galileo presented it to the world. But he hardly published, and few have heard of him.. If the name doesn't ring a bell, you are far from alone. Harriot is one of those bygone geniuses, famous in their own time, now secreted in some neglected cranny of collective memory.

title: Paris Review Publisher Lived for Literature and Fun
summary: Susannah Hunnewell worked for the quarterly magazine over nearly three decades. Susannah Hunnewell infused the Paris Review with an irreverent, cosmopolitan sensibility that reflected the lifetime she spent shuttling between France and the East Coast.

title: Albany Passes on Changing Admissions to New York City's Elite Schools
summary: Bill pushed by Mayor Bill de Blasio went nowhere in state Senate session. This spring's New York state legislative session ended Friday morning with little headway on a bill pushed by Mayor Bill de Blasio to scrap the entrance exam for New York City's elite high schools.

title: Fashion's Jason Wu on Decorating and Matching Furniture to Your Pets
summary: The fashion designer, releasing a new collection of upholstered furniture this month, talks interior design challenges, his decorating faux pas, and risky paint colors. WHEN FIRST LADYMichelle Obama wore one of Jason Wu's dresses early in his career, she instantly conferred name-to-know status on the young fashion designer. Now he's trying to expand that name recognition into décor. On June 27, two sofas, a love seat, chair and ottoman he designed will debut on Interior Define, an online direct-to-consumer furniture retailer, its first collaboration with a fashion designer.

title: Alexa Gone Bad: When A.I. Assistants Turn On Us
summary: In the new 'Child's Play' film, the wicked Chucky doll is reconceived as an A.I. assistant. But what if our real smart-home helpers rebel in less murderous ways?. NOW THAT the "Smart Home of the Future" is finally here, we can shout at A.I. assistants like Amazon's Alexa to start manipulating our fancy TVs, lamps and coffee makers-then shout at them again when, as so often happens, they fail us. It's no wonder sci-fi books and movies often assume robots will turn on humanity. That's essentially what happens in the reboot of the "Child's Play" horror series, in which the smart-yet-sinister Chucky doll, reconceived as a walking Alexa-like device, goes in for the kill.

title: Moj Mahdara on Putting Finances Before Beauty
summary: The BeautyCon CEO says women should cultivate conversations on building wealth. It's time for women to speak freely about their finances, says Moj Mahdara, an entrepreneur and chief executive of BeautyCon Media Inc. Since 2011, BeautyCon has become a key event for influencers and brands in the beauty industry.

title: Top Republican Sees Sanders, Warren as Good for GOP Prospects
summary: In interview, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy said he is optimistic GOP can take back the House in 2020. The results of the Democratic presidential primary may not only determine which party wins the White House in 2020 but also who controls Congress-or so Republicans posit.

title: Lego's Quest to Make Plant-Based Toy Bricks Is Met With Skepticism
summary: WSJ readers weigh in on the company's efforts, and suggest alternatives. Lego A/S has poured $150 million into research since 2012 to find a plant-based substitute for its iconic toy bricks. The Danish company's research and development team is experimenting with corn, wheat and sugar cane-sugar being the most promising. But it has been a frustrating journey that has resulted in just 2% of Lego products being made from plants.

title: Preserved by a Fiery Disaster
summary: The Villa of the Papyri was buried by the eruption of Vesuvius, keeping its scrolls and artworks intact.. Sometime in late 79 A.D., the eruption of Vesuvius destroyed Herculaneum, a Roman town of about 5,000 people. Anyone in the wave of scorching volcanic gas was killed, but many buildings were buried with remarkably little damage-including a gigantic Roman villa full of bronze and stone artworks and a collection of scrolls that would otherwise have decayed into dust. The presence of more than a thousand of these scrolls led the house to be named the Villa of the Papyri.

title: Trump Mounts New Push on Health Care Ahead of 2020 Election
summary: President plans series of actions to focus on high health costs; Democrats counter they will keep lead on health-care issues in 2020. President Trump is planning a series of marquee actions on health care that coincide with his re-election campaign, part of an effort to gain ground on the issue while Democratic presidential candidates debate how far to go in expanding federal coverage.

title: Airlines Avoid Persian Gulf After Downed Drone
summary: Heightened military activity has raised fears for civilian aircraft in one of the world's heaviest trafficked regions. Airlines rerouted flights Friday to avoid airspace over the Persian Gulf after Iran shot down an American military drone, disrupting air travel around one of the world's busiest transportation hubs.

title: When a Pipe Bursts at Amazon, This Engineer Jumps Into Action
summary: What it means to work as a DevOps engineer, solving problems and searching for 'light bulb' moments. Nancy Nims considers herself a keeping-the-lights-on engineer.

title: Stocks to Watch: UnitedHealth, PayPal, Sprouts Farmers Market, and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Friday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Japanese Security Companies Benefit From U.S.'s China Concerns
summary: 'It's a huge opportunity,' says NEC, a supplier of facial-recognition technology. TOKYO-Japanese suppliers of facial-recognition technology and other security equipment are getting a leg up from a U.S. campaign to reduce reliance on China.

title: Fed's Clarida: 'We'll Act as Appropriate to Sustain Expansion'
summary: Fed vice chairman says uncertainty about global economy has risen in past six to eight weeks. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said Friday that the central bank stands ready to lower interest rates if necessary but added that the broad outlook for the U.S. economy remains positive.

title: The U.S. Men's Soccer Team Gets Another Shot at Trinidad and Tobago
summary: The Americans are hoping to exorcise demons against the Soca Warriors-the team that cost them a World Cup berth. The Trinidad and Tobago men's national soccer team was stationed in Minnesota with a problem. The Soca Warriors were days away from a rematch with the U.S. and a chance to reprise the most notorious win in their history. They needed a team to help prepare them.

title: Divorce Rates Are Dropping, Unless You're 55 or Older
summary: Younger married couples are less likely to split up, but 'gray' divorces among older couples are on the rise. It's June, one of the most popular months of the year to marry. So perhaps it's time we talked about divorce.

title: Why the World's Biggest Property Company Is Bailing Out a Bank
summary: China Evergrande Group has paid nearly a 40% premium to raise its stake in undercapitalized Chinese bank Shengjing. Property developers need close relationships with banks-but not usually equity stakes in them. A bank investment by the world's largest property company by assets hints at further trouble in the Chinese financial system.

title: A Look at Boris Johnson, the Favored Candidate to Be Britain's Next Prime Minister
summary: A look at Britain's leading candidate for prime minister, from Oxford student to foreign secretary.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Johnson, Inching Closer to U.K. Leadership, Cozies Up to Trump
summary: After a frosty start, the U.K. leadership front runner is cultivating close ties with the Trump administration. LONDON-When Boris Johnson last visited the White House in 2018, Britain's then foreign secretary surprised aides by wandering around, entering doors at random to greet staffers and bumping into President Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner. "Everyone was saying, 'You are not allowed to do that,'" said one person present.

title: Coke and Pepsi Want to Sell You Bottled Water Without the Bottle
summary: The soda giants are planning for a future where single-use plastic bottles may be banned.

title: The World Doesn't Need Trouble in Chinese Steel
summary: Resume Subscription. The world's largest steel industry is coming under pressure again. That's bad news for Western steelmakers and China alike.

title: Art Looks Better in Private Collections
summary: Sale of Sotheby's takes one of the few listed art companies off the market-but such stocks haven't lived up to investment hopes anyway. The art world has been on a tear since the financial crisis. But you wouldn't suspect it from the share price of Sotheby's , the 275-year-old auction house that this week was sold to French telecom billionaire Patrick Drahi for $3.7 billion including debt. It will find a better home in his private collection than investment portfolios-an argument that applies to publicly traded art assets generally.

title: Former UBS Banker in China Convicted in Cross-Border Insider Trading Case
summary: Ex-banker sentenced to nine years in prison in case involving $6.3 billion takeover by Cosco Shipping Holdings. A former banker from UBS 's Shanghai office was sentenced to nine years in prison in a case involving leaks about a $6.3 billion takeover by Cosco Shipping Holdings Co.

title: Americans Aren't Sure U.S. System Can Fix Long-Term Problems, Poll Finds
summary: A majority believes the nation's best years are in the past. Americans have little faith the U.S. political system can address long-term challenges and are skeptical the nation remains committed to foundational tenets such as the free market, majority rule and tolerance, a Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll shows.

title: Europe Pushes for Commercial Drone Expansion, Possibly Using AI
summary: At the Paris Air Show, several companies disclose ideas for opening up additional airspace for unmanned aircraft. LE BOURGET, France-Europe's aviation industry and regulators are eager to significantly expand commercial drone operations in coming years, including harnessing artificial intelligence for air-traffic control.

title: Prosecutors Intensify Scrutiny of Trump Fundraiser Elliott Broidy
summary: Federal probe examines foreigners who attended inauguration at invitation of top Trump fundraiser. Federal prosecutors have stepped up a criminal investigation into possible efforts by longtime Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy to profit from his connections to the Trump administration, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Cuba Ration Lines Grow Tense as Economy Flails
summary: On island hit by U.S. sanctions and Venezuela downturn, Cubans flash back to post-Soviet hardships. HAVANA-A 91-year-old former comrade of Cuba's late dictator Fidel Castro recently startled Cubans when he announced government plans to breed ostriches to help feed the masses.

title: It's OK to Feel Ambivalent About Your Children
summary: Boredom and loss of identity are common emotions among parents. The problem starts when they are left unexpressed.. Unlike many of his friends, Paul, a divorced 43-year-old publisher in Brooklyn, wasn't nervous about having children. But now that he has them-two daughters, ages 13 and 3-he regularly finds himself fantasizing about how great life would be without them. (Parents' names have been changed throughout to protect privacy.)

title: Hating the Fed Is as American as Apple Pie
summary: The tone of Trump's attacks is new even if the sentiment isn't. But try living without a central bank.. When President Trump complains about the Federal Reserve, he's taking part in a tradition of central-bank bashing that stretches back to America's founding. But for all the missteps the Fed has made over the years, the country is better off with it than it would be without it.

title: In Sunny Cannes, Marketers Fret Over Dark Content Online
summary: Attendees at the marketing industry's biggest gathering worried about brand safety and data privacy. The Cannes Lions ad festival is a sunny fixture for many in marketing, an annual ritual of schmoozing on the French Riviera, drinking ever-present rosé and sounding off on panels about the industry and creativity.

title: Five Takeaways From the June Fed Meeting
summary: Fed Chairman Powell sounds prepared to cut interest rates if growth prospects don't suddenly improve. The Federal Reserve's decision to leave rates unchanged this week while signaling readiness to cut them if the economic outlook doesn't improve soon sent stocks to new highs Thursday, while bond yields reached their lowest levels since 2016.

title: Fed's Rosengren Says Japan's Banks Face Challenges
summary: Boston Fed president cites shrinking population, aging demographics and low interest rates. Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren said Friday that challenging times lie ahead for Japanese banks.

title: U.S. Planned Strike Against Iran but Called Off Mission
summary: Officials say a future military response hasn't been ruled out. The U.S. was preparing to launch a retaliatory strike against Iran for shooting down an American reconnaissance drone Thursday, but the mission was called off at the last minute, U.S. officials said.

title: Gun Makers Adjust Rifles to Skirt Bans
summary: Resume Subscription. California first banned the sale of guns it calls assault weapons, including AR-15 style rifles, in 1989, then updated the restrictions in 1999 and again in 2016.

title: Trump to Nominate Mark Esper to Be Secretary of Defense
summary: Federal rules will require temporary appointment of a new acting secretary, meaning four top Pentagon officials in three years for Trump. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Friday night he would formally nominate Army Secretary Mark Esper to be the next U.S. defense secretary in coming weeks. But federal rules dictate that Mr. Esper step aside temporarily from running the Pentagon while he prepares for the confirmation process.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Gather Outside Government's Central Offices
summary: Government shuts offices as protesters keep up pressure on the city's leader after mass rallies over extradition proposal. HONG KONG-Hong Kong's government closed its central offices on Friday as several hundred demonstrators gathered outside the complex, renewing protests over the government's handling of an unpopular extradition proposal and earlier demonstrations.

title: Former WeWork Executives Allege Gender, Age Discrimination
summary: Suits come as WeWork prepares for IPO. WeWork Cos. is being sued by two former executives who are accusing the shared-office company of gender and age discrimination as it gears up for an initial public offering.

title: After Scattered Efforts, Congress Weighs Blanket Tax Breaks for Disaster Victims
summary: Proposal would create tax provisions that would apply to all major disasters, rather than having Congress pass them case-by-case. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers are attempting to impose structure on tax breaks for disaster victims, seeking an end to a haphazard process that often leads to uneven results and leaves some people waiting years for relief.

title: Zion Williamson Goes No. 1; Three Duke Players Selected in Top 10
summary: As widely expected, Ja Morant was taken by the Grizzlies at No. 2, while the Knicks grabbed RJ Barrett at No. 3. Zion Williamson stared down the 2019 NBA Draft with little uncertainty. He knew he would be picked first-the basketball community long ago anointed the 6-foot 7-inch, 285-pound phenom as the top prospect in the draft class of 2019. And he knew he would land in New Orleans ever since the Pelicans got the lucky ping-pong ball at the draft lottery in mid-May.

title: Enterprise-Technology Companies Trigger Investor Zeal
summary: Recent market debuts show continued enthusiasm for business-facing tech. Slack Technologies Inc.'s soaring market debut on Thursday was the latest example of investors' unquenchable appetite for tech companies building modern digital services for other businesses.

title: Federal Court Weighs Border Wall Funding Case
summary: Appeals court must decide whether projects using funds not appropriated by Congress can proceed. A federal appeals court grappled Thursday with whether the Trump administration should be allowed to proceed with construction projects for a southern U.S. border wall using funds that haven't been approved by Congress.

title: EU Threatens Sanctions on Turkey Amid Drilling Spat
summary: Threats add to pressure on Erdogan, who already faces U.S. actions over planned purchase of Russian missile-defense system. BRUSSELS-European Union leaders threatened sanctions against Turkey as a fight escalated over offshore energy reserves in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Sealed Air Fires CFO, Citing SEC Investigation
summary: Sealed Air turns to CEO Ted Doheny's former No. 2 at Joy Global for next CFO. Sealed Air Corp. fired Chief Financial Officer Bill Stiehl in relation to a yearlong investigation of the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said.

title: Albany Nears Passage of Bill to Decriminalize Pot
summary: New York lawmakers move to further decriminalize marijuana after a larger effort to legalize the drug collapsed. New York state lawmakers moved to further decriminalize marijuana Thursday after a larger effort to legalize the drug collapsed.
